content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "SHORTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: i liked it very interesting
Revised with no guesses after the game has ended. added reversed guess test case

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: I would be more happy, if the text would conform to the English syntax.

Every puzzle is a precedent for later contributions and showing a remiss description may lead more issues in the future and not only in the text.

Testing could be a bit more elaborated, eg trivial case, reversed or unordered trivial case, 6 incorrect quess with 6< word length,...

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good puzzle, only issue is the test cases have guesses after the game is decided. Hopefully they will be edited so that the guesses stop once the game is won/lost.

This is cool, but I think it's a bit artificial to have incorrect guesses after already winning. e.g. your first example is won after guessing 'a' but then there is an 'x' guess afterwards. This would never happen in a real game and makes the puzzle unnecessarily harder (i.e. if you simply count the number of guessed letters that aren't in the word you get 4, but the correct hangman only has 3 appendages).

I think this would be a nicer puzzle if you removed any superfluous guesses (including >6 incorrect guesses, since once you've lost you stop guessing).

"all guesses are valid characters that could be in word with no repeats"

What does this mean?

If it means that all guessed letters are different, then validator 1 is wrong ('i' is twice).
In this case the algorithm could be more simple.

If it means that any guessed letter can only be once in word, then several tests and validators are wrong (eg 'e' in validator 2). I guess that you did not mean that :)

Anyway, I also suggest that the solution should conform to PEP / PEP8 in case of python and should be clean code (exact meaningful names, pythonic, functions, ...)

Note for the algorithm:
Either use a hangman list with the possible hangmans ([' 0 \n/|\\\n/ \\\n', ...] or with multiline strings),
or a list of the drawing info (eg draw '0' at the index 1 position).

Anyway, I like the game.

I would write in the Output chapter:
>>
3 lines: a 3x3 character (including spaces) empty or partial or full hangman

The possible hangmans in order:
    0  0  0  0  0  0 
       | /| /|\/|\/|\
               /  / \

4th line: *Won* or *Lost* depending on the result of the game
<<

There is a problem in the autogenerated C and Objective-C though. It is scanning a word of length 21, while the validator has a longer word. Consider increasing it in the stub generator to be in line with the constraints.
Very nice! Gave it a go now and everything works as it should.
If downvoting please say why so I can improve it
Thank you for the catch, was a typo. The constraint was correct.

Meant no guesses repeated, so it didnt guess 'a' 8 times. Hopefully clear now.

Modified the indents on the hangman definition to follow pep8 exactly, although it was in a generally accepted format. The only thing I see that isnt pythonic is the break, but i put it like that to make it insanely more readable. That entire for loop could be condensed, but then no-one can read it. 

Explicitly defining each hangman in a list/dict/etc would be a little bit easier to understand than a string slice, but wanted the sample code to show how you can copy-paste from the problem very easily in most languages.
Yeah, I was thinking about that, but thought it might be a bit too easy. Lets see what someone else thinks too, but definitely a possibility.
Was checking comments, what do you mean by conform to the English syntax and a remiss description?

Sentences start with capital letter and ends with point.

Some examples for what I mean on remiss:
"Second Line: Number of guesses" - here, first word after ':' (Number) starts with capital, but not at other places. This is inconsistent style.
The text seems to me some slang at many places:
"all games are either won or lost, no extra guesses"
"6 incorrect guesses is a win" - win or won term inconsistency

I don't think that makes it too easy, and making it more difficult by such an artificial complication takes away from the elegance of the puzzle. You've added a hurdle that isn't realistic just to make the puzzle more complicated.

"with no repeated guesses"  -->  >>without repetition<<

The 'i' guess is still twice in the validator 1.
If somebody relies on the no repetition constraint, one will be angry loosing time to reverse engineering this validator. :-(

"ascii art" - why not using the exact expression (empty or partial or full hangman)?

These are not simply samples, but the possible expected outputs.

Hints for coding is doubtfully useful (generally).
In case of shortest mode, this is the best recipe not to be in the first 3. 
Eg in bash,  you may not need escaping back slash.

Still not PEP8, spaces around operators, after comma. you can use PEP8 parsers.

Pythonic: "len(word) == 0"  --> >>word<<

"for i in range(n)"  -->  >>while n and bad_guesses < 6:<<  >>n -= 1<<
with this no break is needed.

In case of unique guessed letters constraint, no deletion of the letters are needed.
In this case, the count of wrong guesses can be:
sum(guess not in word for guess in map(input, [''] * n))
or
sum(input() not in word for i in range(n))
This is not optimized, but you did not make test for optimal solution and the number of guesses can be max 26.

In the case of the oops test, the word is solved, but after the 6 wrong guesses. This would mess up some of the list compression solutions where you are just counting correct or wrong guesses, the order does matter. Added a test to make this more clear.

Fixed the duplicate letter in the validator, completely missed that. 

Will work on making the code a lot better, and maybe a shortest version. I originally just thought the solution was meant to explain how to do it in beginner terms, not as an expected solution.

Yes, the solution is mean to explain and check the tests.

So, it would be nicer if the "normal" solution would remain.

A short solution is not more professional at all, just it is a challenge of this game.
